subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Fire Temples: Zoroastrianism's Living Flame
description: A quick win: understand Fire Temples: Zoroastrianism's Living Flame.

hook.text: Some Zoroastrian fires have burned for over a thousand years. Fire isn't worshipped â€” it's the symbol of God's truth.

buildup.text: Zoroastrian temples maintain an eternal flame. The fire represents Ahura Mazda's truth, wisdom, and divine light.

discovery.text: Worshippers pray facing the fire but don't worship it. The flame is a focus for devotion, like a Christian cross.

twist.text: Outsiders called them 'fire-worshippers.' The label stuck for centuries. Zoroastrians have fought this lie for ages.

climax.text: Only 100,000 Zoroastrians remain worldwide. But their sacred fires still burn, connecting them to a 3,500-year past.

punchline.text: 100,000 believers, 3,500 years of fire. Zoroastrianism refuses to die.

quiz.question: What does fire represent in Zoroastrianism?
